titles.ja: 宮城県　火伏せの虎舞
titles.en: Tiger Dance Festival at Miyagi

descriptions.en:
Kami is a small town located in the north-western part of Miyagi Prefecture.  The area has suffered from multiple fires because of the massive gush of dry wind that comes from the mountains.  It is said that Hibuse no Toramai, or “Tiger Dance Festival for Fire Prevention” was first started by Iekane Shiba, who was posted to Kami 650 years ago to
help with the town’s fire prevention planning.  
Tora no Mai, or “Tiger Dance”, is danced by children between the ages of 11-15.  It is a duet; the two dancers cover themselves with a tiger print fabric, while the child in front holds a tiger mask with both hands, and the child behind holds a stick representing the tail.  The Tiger Dance is meant to defuse the strong winds with the power of the tiger.  We follow the kids as they practice for their performance at the festival.
descriptions.ja:
宮城県の北西部に位置する加美町。山から吹き降ろす乾いた風のために昔から大きな火災が頻繁におきていました。およそ650年前、この地に赴任した斯波家兼が火災予防の意味を込めて始めたとされるのが”火伏せの虎舞”です。
 虎の舞を踊るのは小学6年生から中学3年生までの子供達。2人1組で虎柄の布を被り、前の人は虎の面を両手で持ち、後ろの人はシッポに見立てた棒を立てながら息を合わせて踊ります。虎舞には虎の威力で風を鎮め火伏せになるようにという願いが込められています。
 祭りの主役の子供達を練習風景から本番までを追いかけてこの祭りを紹介します。

titles.ja: 秋田県　沢田ろうそくまつり
titles.en: Sawada Candle Festival in Aomori

descriptions.en: Sawada Candle Festival is a unique festival which has been held on January 15th on the lunar calendar for more than 450 years in the Sawada area of Hirosaki city in Aomori. This area is also called “the village where Heike fugitives settled down,” and at the beginning of this festival, it is said that the people held a memorial service for those deceased in the Heike clan who perished at the Dan no Ura battle in 1185.
descriptions.ja:
450年以上前から青森県弘前市沢田地区で毎年旧暦の小正月1月15日に行われている奇祭が沢田ろうそくまつりです。この地区は「平家の落人の里」とも言われていて、このまつりも壇ノ浦の戦いで滅んだ平家の霊を住民が供養したのが始まりとも言われています。
 沢田神明宮にある岩谷堂と呼ばれる天然の洞窟の岩肌にろうそくを立てて五穀豊穣や合格祈願などの思いを託して明かりを灯しロウの溶けた形を見て作物の豊凶や願い事が占われます。稲穂のように垂れていれば作柄は良いとされ、手のひらを広げたような形で先に玉のような粒があると幸せな年になると言われています。

titles.ja: 秋田県　六郷のカマクラ行事
titles.en: Kamakura Festival at Rokugō

descriptions.en:
Kamakura (Ice House) Festival is a winter tradition in the town of Rokugō, Akita Prefecture; also known as the land of spring water.  For many, Yokote kamakuras are the more popular style igloos, but Rokugō kamakuras have been around for more than 400 years.  Rokugō kamakuras are built in the shape of a box, rather than a round shape like Yokote kamakuras.  
The highlight of the Kamakura Festival is an event called Take-uchi.  Men are divided into the “North team” and “South team”.  As they fight each other with long bamboo sticks, their cries and the sound of the clashing bamboo echo throughout the cold night.  Kamakuras hold different meanings depending on how they came to be and their traditions; Yokote’s Kamakura represents calmness, while the Rokugō Kamakura represents movement.
descriptions.ja: 湧水の里として知られる秋田県美郷町六郷の冬の風物詩、カマクラ行事。カマクラと言うと横手のカマクラが有名ですが、六郷のカマクラの歴史はずっと古くおよそ400年前にさかのぼると言われています。さらに横手のカマクラが丸型であるのに対し箱型であることも特徴です。六郷のカマクラ行事のハイライトは南軍と北軍に分かれた男たちが互いに竹で打ち合う「竹打ち」。男たちの雄叫びと竹を打つ音が極寒の冬空に響き渡ります。横手のカマクラが「静」なら、六郷は「動」。同じカマクラでもその周辺でどんな習わしが行われるかで随分と印象が変わります。

titles.ja: 秋田県　三吉梵天祭
titles.en: Miyoshi Bonden Festival in Akita

descriptions.en: This episode covers “Miyoshi Bonden Festival”, the brave fight festival that has been passed down in Akita city in Akita prefecture. According to the program director who has covered many festivals in the Tohoku region, this is one of the top three fierce festivals. It’s also called “Fight Bonden” for its vigor, and the neighboring communities fiercely race each other to be the first to offer their colorful village Bonden to the main shrine. It has been said that the wilder the shoving of the men gets, the happier the festival god would be, and you would receive the power of the god if you are the first to offer the Bonden. The Bonden Festival is held during the coldest time of the year, so it must have been the annual event for people to get through the winter in the frigid region.
descriptions.ja: 今回は秋田県秋田市に伝わる勇壮なケンカ祭「三吉梵天祭」をご紹介します。これまで東北各地の数多くの祭りを取材してきたディレクターいわく「3本の指に入る激しさ」とのこと。その力強さから「ケンカ梵天」ともよばれるこの祭りは町内ごとに作られた色鮮やかな村梵天をいち早く本殿に奉納しようと激しい先陣争いを繰り広げるもの。男達の押し合いが激しければ激しいほど祭神が喜び最も早く梵天を奉納すると神の力にあやかれるという言い伝えがあります。一年で最も寒い時期に行われる梵天祭。古から厳寒の地で冬を乗り切るための年中行事だったに違いありません。

titles.ja: 福島県　木幡の幡祭り
titles.en: The Banner Festival of Kohata

descriptions.en:
This episode presents the Banner Festival of Kohata as handed down in Nihonmatsu City, Fukushima.
In this festival, which originally stems from a post in the year 1055, more than a hundred banners in a multitude of colors are offered to the shrine. The resounding conch shell and the vivid banners are a reminder of the ending year. The Banner Festival not only welcomes the New Year, it is also a rite of adulthood. A precious custom has those participating for the first time, called“gondachi,” eat rice porridge as a weaning ceremony. 
This time, local high school students act as “gondachi” and perform water ablutions. The many cameramen who came to photograph the beautiful festival witnessed the emotions of the people watching over the growth of the local young men.
descriptions.ja: 今回は福島県二本松市に伝わる木幡の幡祭りをご紹介します。前九年（1055年）の役に由来するこの祭りは五色に彩られた百数十本の旗を神社に奉納するもので法螺貝の響きと共に鮮やかな五反幡を押し立てる風景は師走の風物詩となっています。幡祭りは新年を迎えるための祭礼であるだけでなく成人となるための儀式でもあります。初めて参加する人を「権立」（ごんだち）と呼び「食い初め」に見立てて粥を食べるなど貴重な風習が残っています。今回は地元の高校生が権立として水垢離から参加しました。多くのカメラマンが足を運ぶ美しい祭りには、地域の青年の成長を見守る人々の思いが息づいています。

titles.ja: 福島県　岡山の水かけ祭り
titles.en: Okayama ‘Water Splashing’ Festival

descriptions.en: This program features a ‘water splashing’ festival observed in Okayama, Fukushima City, Fukushima Prefecture. Designated as an important intangible folk culture asset of Fukushima, it is considered as one of three major unusual festivals. In the past, when Okayama villagers suffered an epidemic disease and famine, a girl appeared with an oracle telling them to splash pond waters at each other. Once they put her words into practice, the disease subsided and a good harvest was reaped. On the day of the festival, along with servings of doburoku brewed by locals, water is splashed about with high-spirited shouts. Water is unsparingly thrown on spectators too, because legend has it that people who have water showered on them will become happy. Proudly retaining a 800-year-old tradition, the festival is celebrated with wishes for the region’s prosperity and happiness.
descriptions.ja: 今回は福島県福島市岡山に伝わる伝統の「水かけ祭り」をご紹介します。福島県の重要無形民俗文化財に指定されるこの祭りは天下の三大奇祭と伝えられる珍しい祭りです。その昔、大凶作と悪病に見舞われた岡山の里。そこに現れた少女のお告げ通り沼の水をかけあったところたちまち悪病は退散、豊作に湧いたそうです。祭り当日。地元の人々の手で作られたどぶろくが振る舞われると威勢の良いかけ声と共に水かけが始まります。祭りの見物客にも容赦なく水が浴びせられるのは水を受けると幸せになるという言い伝えがあるためです。800年の伝統を誇る祭りは地域の繁栄と幸せを願う祭りなのです。

titles.ja: 福島県　二本松の提灯祭り
titles.en: The Lantern Festival in Nihonmatsu

descriptions.en:
This episode presents the Lantern Festival of Nihonmatsu City, Fukushima. This festival, which has been designated an important intangible folk culture asset of Fukushima, is a unique festival where a float with about 300 lit lanterns is paraded through the town.
Many visitors from other prefectures come to see the autumn sky magically colored by countless paper lanterns at this pre-festival festival. It is held in preparation to greet the gods the following day when the true festival will be held.
A portable shrine together with the musical accompaniment parades through the town and up the stairs of the shrine for a heroic climax.
The stillness of the lanterns interwoven with the motion of the portable shrine and its carriers is the charm of this festival.
descriptions.ja: 今回は福島県二本松市に伝わる提灯祭りをご紹介します。福島県の重要無形民俗文化財に指定されるこの祭りは、太鼓台と呼ばれる約300個の提灯を灯 した山車を引き回す独特の祭りです。秋の夜空を無数の提灯が幻想的に彩るこの「宵祭り」を目当てに県内外から多くの観光客が訪れますが、これは神を迎える ための準備であり、実は翌日の「本祭り」に向けた序章なのです。神輿はお囃子と共に一日かけて町内を練り歩き神社の階段を神輿が駆け上が勇壮なクライマッ クスへと向います。提灯が織り成す「静」と担ぎ手と神輿が生み出す「動」こそがこの祭りの醍醐味なのです。

titles.ja: 秋田県　やまぶっつけ
titles.en: Float Crashing Festival in Akita

descriptions.en:
This program features the Yama Event of Kakunodate Festival, an important intangible folk cultural asset which has been handed down in Akita Prefecture.
Its origin is from a float parade that was held in the 17th century to try and comfort a lord’s bride from Kyoto who cried thinking of her home. 
Eighteen floats built by each community in Kakunodate proceed through narrow streets according to their planned routes. 
When two floats come across each other, they negotiate over the right of way. A negotiation may continue for a few hours.
If a negotiation breaks off, they try to pass through forcibly by hitting each other’s floats.
The festival lasts three days in a former castle town where samurais thought highly of their faith.
descriptions.ja: 今回は秋田に伝わる国の重要無形民俗文化財、角館祭りのやま行事をご紹介します。江戸時代初期に殿様に嫁いだ京娘が故郷を偲んで泣くのを慰めるために始めた山鉾祭りが由来。角館町の18の町内で作られた曳山が狭い道をそれぞれが決めたルートで進みます。曳山同士が鉢合わせすると、どちらが先に通るかの交渉が始まり、交渉は数時間に及ぶ事も。決裂すると互いの曳山をぶつけ合い、力ずくで通ろうとします。武士の町らしく筋を通すことを重んじてきた祭りは3日間に渡って行われます。

titles.ja: 秋田県　統人行事 ～スサノオとヤマタノオロチ～
titles.en: Cow Riding and Spider Dance in Akita

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we introduce a curious festival in Akita Prefecture of Cow Riding and Spider Dancing. The two characters of the festival, Susano-o is a god upon a black cow, and Yamatanoorochi, a serpent, is represented clothed in red. This is a well-known story in Japanese mythology, passed on for more than 100 years through this festival in Akita. 
The head of this festival is known by the villagers as Mitsuruhito. The traditional process of the festival takes a year, completing several rituals leading up to the day of the festival. Susano-o, in a ritualistic trance, rides through the town on a black cow, while the serpent dances upon a barge while floating up the river. Through this festival, it is said that the earth is cleansed and happiness is able to visit.
descriptions.ja:
今回は秋田県に伝わる奇祭、牛乗りとくも舞いをご紹介します。
 牛乗りはスサノオをあらわし、くも舞いはヤマタノオロチをあわらしています。
 日本神話の中で良く知られる物語が、千年前から秋田で祭りとして伝え継がれています。祭りを仕切るのは統人と呼ばれる町の人々です。
しきたり通りに1年がかりで数々の神事を行って祭りの当日を迎えます。神がかって意識がもうろうとした牛乗りは黒い牛の背に跨り町内を巡行、くも舞いは川に浮かぶ舟の上で独特の舞いを演じます。この神事によって土地が清められ幸せが訪れると言い伝えられています。

titles.ja: 福島県　相馬野馬追 ～一千余年受け継がれる神と馬と人間の神事～
titles.en: Soma Nomaoi in Fukushima

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we introduce Fukushima Prefecture's Soma Nomaoi, a ritual of over a thousand years of history. 
Some believe that it was initiated by Taira no Masakado, a samurai in the 10th century, then passed down the Soma lineage through generations. Hundreds of horses were freed into vast pastures to be captured by horse-riding warriors and soldiers. Unarmed, the army took a battle formation and captured horses to be offered to local deities. Soma Nomaoi is held in prayer for harmony and happiness among citizens. It is also believed to be the origin of wishing tablets “Ema” of today. 
One feels the spirit of warriors during Soma-Nomaoi. To the townspeople, it continues to be a festival essential and closely connected to the love for their home town.
descriptions.ja:
今回は福島県で千年を越える歴史を持つ神事「相馬野馬追」をご紹介します。
 一説ではこの神事は平将門が始めたものとされ、相馬氏が代々引き継いで行ってきました。広大な牧場に放たれている数百頭の馬を騎馬武者や足軽などが陣形をとって追い込み、素手で捕らえて鎮守の神に奉納していました。
これは領民の平和と幸福を祈る神事で、現在の絵馬の元になったとも言われています。今も武士の魂を感じさせる野馬追は地元の人々にとって欠かせない祭り、かけがえの無いふるさとを愛する心は今も変わっていません。

titles.ja: 青森県　津軽の虫送り
titles.en: Tsugaru Flight of the Insects

descriptions.en: In this episode, we introduce Aomori Prefecture where even now there is a traditional festival called “the flight of the insects”. In farming towns across the country there are plenty of places that pray for a deliverance from pests and a bumper crop following the planting of rice. They continue to this day. In Aomori Prefecture, Tsugaru District, every early summer, there is a festival that brings everyone together to pray for the deliverance from pests. In Tsugaru, the main attraction is a large snake made out of straw. The snake, called mushi makes his way through the town, ridding it of all destructive insects.
descriptions.ja:
今回は青森県で今も行われている伝統行事の虫送りを紹介します。
 全国の農村で田植え後に害虫退散や五穀豊穣の願いを込めて行われた虫送りですが、現在も続けているところは少なくなっています。
 青森県の津軽地方では初夏に近隣の虫送りを一堂に集めた祭りを行っています。津軽の虫送りでは藁で作られた大きな蛇が登場します。
ムシとよばれる蛇が町内を練り歩くことで害虫が退散すると信じられてきました。また、五所川原の虫送りは大名行列の様に盛大に行われたと伝えられ、田植えを終えた農村の人々の楽しみのひとつだったようです。

titles.ja: 青森県　久渡寺の大志羅講　 ～東北に伝わる不思議な守り神～
titles.en: Oshira guardian gods in Aomori

descriptions.en:
Oshira-sama is the household guardian god in the Tohoku region. Oshira-sama is a pair of male and female gods that are made out of mulberry trees, and they are enshrined at home as guardian gods.
The Oshira-koh meeting is held in Kudo-ji temple in Hirosaki city in Aomori prefecture, where many people gather with their Oshira-sama and conduct an important ceremony called “Oshira asobase.”
descriptions.ja:
今回は東北に伝わる家の守り神オシラサマ。オシラサマは桑の木で作られた男女一対のご神体で、守り神として家の中で大切に祀られます。
 青森県弘前市の久渡寺で行われるオシラ講には、大勢がオシラサマを持ち寄り、大切な祭儀「オシラ遊ばせ」を行います。

titles.ja: 山形県　厳島神社例祭・鼠ヶ関の神興流し
titles.en: Mikoshi Nagashi at Nezugaseki

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we visit Tsuruoka city of Yamagata Prefecture. 
We feature the tradition of Mikoshi Nagashi on the island of Benten-jima, Nezugaseki. It is an unusual festival that worships the Benzaiten goddess, whose statue was found and hauled out from the sea. Men known as shojinto purify their bodies by abstaining from meat and fish, then carry a shrine called mikoshi on their shoulders for 5 hours while parading throughout town. They eventually make their way towards the mouth of Nezugaseki river. Along the way, they are offered sake. Unable to walk straight from the alcohol, they carry the mikoshi into the river that is freezing at 6 degrees Celsius. The mikoshi is cleansed with the river water. The ritual is a prayer to Benzaiten for sound health, safety at sea and abundant harvest for the year to come.
descriptions.ja:
今回は山形県鶴岡市。
鼠ヶ関の弁天島に伝わる神輿流しをご紹介します。言い伝えでは海中から引き揚げられた弁財天の仏像を祀って始まったという奇祭。肉や魚を断ち身を清めた精進徒が神輿を担ぎ、5時間もかけて街を練り歩きます。
精進徒は道中で振る舞われる酒を飲み続けながら海に近い鼠ヶ関川の河口を目指します。酔いもまわって足元もおぼつかない精進徒、雪解け水が流れる水温およそ6度の川の中に神輿を担いだまま入っていきます。川の水で神輿を祓い清め、今年1年の無病息災や海上安全、五穀豊穣などを弁財天に祈願します。

titles.ja: 福島県　保原の奇祭「つつこ引き祭」
titles.en: Fukushima’s Tsutsukohiki Festival

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we introduce the Tsutsukohiki Matsuri from Date, in Fukushima Prefecture. 
In this festival, a big bale of straw is pulled in three separate directions to determine the fortunes for the year. According to legend, the town was saved from a severe famine by an oracle who called all the fiefs to the shrine to distribute seeds, which was followed by a bountiful harvest the next year, and this was the beginning of this festival. It was also used as a way to determine where the public market would be set up. Steamed glutinous rice is stuffed into the bale, and it subsequently turns into mochi from the pounding that the bale goes through. At the end of the festival, these mochi rice cakes are scattered to onlookers. The Tsutsukohiki Matsuri is known as the festival to signal the coming of spring to Date.
descriptions.ja:
今回は福島県伊達市に伝わるつつこ引き祭りをご紹介します。
稲藁で編んだ大俵を3方向に引き合い、その年の吉凶を占う祭り。言い伝えでは、大飢饉に見舞われた際、神のお告げを聞いた領主が神社に領民を集めて種籾を配ったところ、翌年は豊作に恵まれたことから始まったとされ、市場町として栄えた時には市場の開設権を賭けて引き合ったと言われます。
大俵の中には蒸かしたもち米が詰めてあり、激しい引き合いが終わる頃にはお餅になっており餅撒きが行われます。つつこ引き祭りは伊達市に春の訪れを告げる奇祭として知られています。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 秋田県　刈和野の大綱引き ～５００年の歴史　大綱引き～
titles.en: The Kariwano Tug-of-War

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we visit Daisen City of Akita Prefecture. 
We introduce the Kariwano Tug-of-War that has been held for over 500 years. It was said that Nagayama, a relative to samurai Taira no Masakado, started the practice as a ritual to worship Ichigami, the god that safeguards the marketplace. In the past, the town of Kariwano would divide into Kami-cho and Shimo-cho, then compete in the tug-of-war for the opening rights of the marketplace. Today, it is used as a form of divination to predict the rice market, but the spirit for victory still remains unchanged. Kami-cho makes the o-zuna rope while Shimo-cho makes the me-zuna rope. The battle starts as soon as the 2 ropes are joined as one. It is an eye opener to see thousands come together, shouting as they pull on the large rope.
descriptions.ja:
今回は秋田県大仙市。
500年以上も続いている刈和野の大綱引きをご紹介します。言い伝えでは平将門一族の、長山氏が市場を守護する市神をこの地に祀って綱引きを始めたとされています。刈和野の町を上町と下町とに2分して綱引き勝負で市場の開設権を争った歴史があります。今は米の豊作占いの意味に変わってはいますが、綱引き勝負に掛ける男たちの意気込みは変わりません。上町が作る雄綱と下町が作る雌綱、それを繋ぎ合わせて1本の大綱が完成したら勝負が始まります。数千人が弾けるような掛け声と共に大綱を引き合う様は圧巻です。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 宮城県　えんずのわり ～こどもたちが守る故郷の神事～
titles.en: Enzunowari: A ritual by children

descriptions.en: This episode features “Enzunowari”, a traditional ritual dating back more than 200 years in Tsukihama, a village in Higashi-matsushima, Miyagi Prefecture. The ritual originated from the village having to protect their livelihood, after frequently having the crops eaten by birds, and the tradition is passed down to boys aged 8 to 14. As the messengers of the gods, the boys confine themselves in a grotto near the shrine and cook their own vegetarian food to eat, as a way of cleansing their bodies. The boys also go around the village, praying and singing for the residents’ health and the revitalization of their tsunami-struck village. The tsunami disaster brought about talk of ceasing the practice, but the boys themselves requested for it to continue.
descriptions.ja: 今回は宮城県東松島市の月浜で200年以上続く小正月の鳥追い行事「えんずのわり」を紹介します。半農半漁だった時代に畑を食い荒らす鳥を追い払い、暮らしを守るために始まったとされる行事。小学2年から中学2年までの男子が受け継いできました。神の使いになる為、子ども達は神社の岩屋にお篭りをし、自分達でこしらえた精進料理を食べて心身を清めます。現在は震災被害に遭った浜の復興や人々の健康祈願を祈って家々をまわり、唱え歌を唄います。震災直後は中止も検討されましたが、子ども達の強い希望で、途絶えること無く続けられています。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 宮城県　島田飴まつり
titles.en: The Shimada Candy Festival

descriptions.en: In this episode, we introduce the Shimada Candy Festival. It is a festival of over 400 years of history, in Taiwa town, Miyagi Prefecture. At the end of each year, it is held for many to pray for good luck in love in the year to come. The story behind the festival is said to be of a priest that was love-stricken after seeing a beautiful bride in a traditional Shimada hairstyle. To the priest who had fallen ill from yearning, worried villagers offered his shrine a candy shaped like the Shimada hairstyle. He recovered immediately. Since then, the Shimada candy is an element quintessential to the festival of love and marriage. Many locals and tourists come from afar for the Shimada candy. Only 1500 are made every year.
descriptions.ja: 今回は宮城県大和町で400年以上に渡って続く縁結びの祭りをご紹介します。毎年暮れに翌年の良縁を願って行われる島田飴まつり、その発端は高島田に結った美しいお嫁さんに一目惚れをした神社の神主さんの恋煩いにあると言い伝えられ、病で寝込んでしまった神主さんを心配した村の人々が高島田をかたどった飴を作り神社に奉納したところ病気が回復したと言います。以来、縁結びの神事を行うようになり島田飴は祭りには欠かせない縁起物になりました。限定で1500個作られる島田飴を求めて、県内、県外から参拝者が訪れ賑わいを見せています。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 福島県　炎の祭り松明あかし
titles.en: The Torch Testimony of Fukushima

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we introduce Taimatsu Akashi, or “Torch Testimony”, an undying tradition of over 400 years in Sukagawa City, Fukushima. 
The Nikaido family of old Sukagawa fell into a civil war started by the young Date Masamune, who sought to unify the Oshu region. Older sister to Masamune's father, lord of the time Daijo-in was pressed to decide whether or not to engage in war with the Date clan. War soon commenced after vassals and residents expressed their resolve to fight. The violent war ended in many lives lost and the surrender of the Nikaido castle. 
Still in practice today, a total of 29 ten-meter tall taimatsu are lit during the Torch Testimony to mourn for all who died in battle. It is here that people honor their predecessors who laid the foundation for the city today.
descriptions.ja:
今回は福島県須賀川市で400年以上に渡って続く松明あかしをご紹介します。
 奥州統一の戦いを始めた若き日の伊達政宗、その戦乱に巻き込まれた須賀川の二階堂家。時の城主は政宗の父の姉となる大乗院、伊達家と戦うか否か選択を迫られます。その時、家臣に加え領民も立ち上がり、戦う決意を大乗院に進言、ついに戦いの火蓋が切って落とされます。激しい攻防で多くの命が失われ、城は落城。今も続く松明あかしは戦没者の霊を弔う為に高さ10メートルの巨大な松明29本を立て御神火を放ちます。礎となった先人達への感謝の気持ちを込めて祈ります。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 宮城県　鳴子温泉郷 ～千年の歴史を刻む湯の里～
titles.en: Miyagi’s Hot Spring Village Naruko

descriptions.en: This episode introduces the rituals in Naruko, a hot spring village in Miyagi Prefecture, that have continued for over 400 years, as worship to the deity of hot springs. Volcanic eruptions have led to the formation of the hot springs in the Heian period, and imperial officials have worshiped the hot spring deities since. The 'Kentoshiki' is a ritual where water from the hot spring inns is placed into buckets and offered to the gods at the shrine. It is rare to see such an ancient tradition still practiced today, and it is a testament to how much the people of Naruko cherish this gift from the gods.
descriptions.ja: 今回は湯の神を祭る神事を400年に渡って続けている宮城の鳴子温泉郷を紹介します。火山噴火により温泉が湧いたのは平安時代、朝廷はこの地に湯の神を祭りました。献湯式という名の神事は鳴子にある温泉宿の源泉の湯を桶に入れ温泉神社の湯の神に捧げるものです。古式にのっとり今も続けている温泉郷は珍しく、鳴子の人々が神様から授けられた温泉を大切にする心が伝わる行事です。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 青森県  ～賑やかな聖なる行進～
titles.en: The Sacred Mount Iwaki

descriptions.en: This time we introduce the ancient “mountain prayer” at Aomori Prefecture’s Mt. Iwaki. Once a year, participants in the ritual climb to a Shinto shrine on the peak, and pray for peace and a rich harvest as the rays of the morning sun strike the mountain. As they do so they carry wooden wands called Gohei, and a banner that weights as much as 40 kilograms. They also sing a chant unique to the ritual:  “Saigi, Saigi, dokkaoisaigi!” Since the building of the shrine 1200 years ago, participants have waited for the sunrise after paying their respects to the mountain.
descriptions.ja:
今回は青森県の岩木山で古くから行われている「お山参詣」をご紹介します。
 年に一度、岩木山の山頂に登ってご来光を浴び、五穀豊穣と家内安全を願う神事です。参詣者は御幣や重さが40キロもある大きな幟を掲げ山道を進みます。「サイギ、サイギ、ドッコイサイギ」、独特の囃子言葉を唱えながら隊列を組み山頂を目指します。千二百年前に建立されたという岩木山神社の奥宮でお払いを受けたあと神聖な山の頂で、ご来光を待つのです。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 宮城県 金華山黄金山神社
titles.en: Kinkasan Koganeyama Shrine of Miyagi

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we visit Kinkasan Koganeyama Shrine of Miyagi Prefecture. 
Mt. Kinkasan became known nation-wide since its enshrinement of Benzaiten (also known as Saraswati, the god of wealth). The temple that was eventually built here in a time of religious union between Shintoism and Buddhism became a pilgrimage destination for monks from all over the country. In the Edo period, it was also popular among the masses to visit Benzaiten to receive blessings for good fortune. Every 12 years, in the year of the Snake, a grand festival is held throughout autumn in dedication to Benzaiten and its snake messenger.
descriptions.ja:
今回は宮城県の金華山黄金山神社を訪ねます。
金華山は金を司る神を祭る島として古くから知られ、神仏習合の時代には寺院が建ち、各地から多くの修行僧が訪れました。当時、島に弁財天が祭られ、その名は全国に広まります。弁財天詣りは金運のご利益があると、江戸時代には民衆の間でも盛んに行われました。弁財天の使者は蛇で巳年の今年は12年に一度の特別な年で、秋にかけて特別な大祭が行われます。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.en: Yake-Hachiman of Yanagisawa

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we introduce the customary practice of Yake-Hachiman in Yanagisawa of Kami city, Miyagi Prefecture. Passed on from the old farming village of Miyazaki (formerly part of Kami city), the practice is a prayer for bountiful harvest and good health, as much as it is an event that unifies the region.
The 2-day procession of Yake-Hachiman starts with youths visiting the Hachiman shrine naked in the cold, after having cleansed their bodies with sacred wine. They proceed to visit all households in town to distribute the sacred wine. Lastly, a hut built specially for this event is set on fire, while people put their hands together to pray for good health.
descriptions.ja:
今回は宮城県加美町に伝わる柳沢の焼け八幡をご紹介します｡ 旧宮崎町の農村で受け継がれてきた行事は､豊作と無病息災を祈る他に､地域の結束を固める役割を果たしています｡
焼け八幡は二日間に渡って行われ､お神酒で身を清めた若者たちが八幡神社に裸参りをした後､お神酒を配りに全戸を回ります｡
最後はこの日のために建てた御小屋に火を放ち､燃え盛る炎に手を合わせ無病息災を祈ります｡

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 秋田県 六郷湧水群
titles.en: Rokugo Yusui-gun Springs of Akita

descriptions.en: This episode features the springs of Rokugo in Misato-cho, Akita Prefecture. Being located on a delta at the foot of the Ou mountains gives Rokugo its underground access to mountain spring waters. Prized as a valuable resource during feudal Japan, the springs were protected by laws that prohibited deforestation at the river source. People of Rokugo town have since utilized and treasured these spring waters in their own ways.
descriptions.ja:
今回は独特の地形から町に数多くの清水が湧く、秋田県美郷町六郷を訪ねます。奥羽山脈の麓にある六郷地区は扇状地の上にあり山の水が地下を通って湧いてきます。藩政時代にはこの水を守るために水源の森の伐採を禁止するなど、
貴重な資源として考えられてきました。また、町に暮らす人々は清水にそれぞれ名を付けて使い方を決め、大切にしてきた歴史があります。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 岩手県 チャグチャグ馬コ
titles.en: Chagu-chagu Umakko of Iwate

descriptions.en: In this episode, we introduce Chagu-chagu Umakko Horse Festival of Takizawa city, Iwate Prefecture. Iwate was known as a horse breeding region during feudal Japan. The use of horses eventually became more exclusive to farming and agriculture, where they are loved and valued by people in the south for toiling in the fields. Held as a prayer for the health of these horses, Chagu-chagu Umakko Horse Festival is a custom that symbolises the deep bond between humans and horses.
descriptions.ja: 岩手県滝沢村に伝わる伝統行事、チャグチャグ馬コをご紹介します。藩政時代、岩手県一帯は南部駒の生産地として知られていました。馬の役割は移り変わり、やがて農耕馬として農民たちの手に渡ります。一緒に汗を流して働く馬は南部の人々に大切にされました。馬の健康を願う風習、チャグチャグ馬コは人と馬との深い絆から生まれた行事なのです。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.en: The sacred folktales of Tono

descriptions.en: In this episode, we visit Tono city in Iwate Prefecture, home to many folktales of Japan. Closely connected with less populated valley regions, these tales feature mythical creatures like tengu (the heavenly dog), kappa (water monster) and zashiki-warashi (child spirit). It is in these serene living conditions where man and nature are one, that such folktales are born. Some of these tales are light-hearted and happy, while some meant to be retold as a lesson to learn. They are a reflection of the life lived by the predecessors of Tono.
descriptions.ja: 岩手県遠野市を訪ねる。不思議な伝説と民話が語り継がれてきた遠野。民話は里山の暮らしと密接に関わるものが多く、てんぐやかっぱ、座敷わらしなどが登場する。自然と人が一体となっておおらかに暮らしているからこそ生まれてくる話。時に愉快で、時に人々を戒める話には先人たちが重ねてきた遠野の暮らしの記憶が刻み込まれている。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.en: The Biggest Ginkgo Tree in Japan

descriptions.en:
In this episode, we head to Fukaura town of Aomori Prefecture where Japan's oldest ginkgo tree stands.
More than a thousand years old, the sacred tree is believed to bless women who have difficulty breastfeeding. This grants the tree its local name, 'Mother Ginkgo'.
Enchanted after a chance encounter with the tree, a Japanese artist revisits and paints the Big Gingko.
descriptions.ja:
今回は青森県深浦町に立つ、樹齢千年を超える日本一の大銀杏を紹介します。
地元では垂乳根の木（たらちねのき）と呼ばれ、母乳不足で悩む女性に乳を授けるご神木として広く信仰を集めていました。そして、この木に運命的に出会い、魅せられた日本画家がいます。画家は今年、大銀杏の元を再び訪ねました。この木を描くためです。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.en: Hinoemata Kabuki

descriptions.en: In this episode, we visit Hinoemata village in Fukushima Prefecture. Developed in the Edo period and introduced to the village more than 270 years ago, Hinoemata Kabuki is esteemed as a preserved dance form of its time. As suggested by its name, Hinoemata Kabuki is performed by people of the Hinoemata village. Built alongside a quiet shrine in the woods is a kabuki theatre, where the dance is performed in dedication to the gods.
descriptions.ja: 今回は福島県桧枝岐村を訪ねます。桧枝岐歌舞伎は、およそ270年以上前に村に伝わったという江戸時代の歌舞伎で、その形を現代に残す貴重な舞として知られています。踊り手はもちろん村人たちです。森の中にひっそりと佇む神社、そこに並ぶように建てられた歌舞伎の舞台、そこで奉納の舞が繰り返し踊られてきたのです。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 宮城・岩手　謎のカマ神様
titles.en: The Mysterious Kamagami of Miyagi and Iwate
titles.it: I misteriosi Kamagami di Miyagi e Iwate

en: - The mask talisman that protects homes -

descriptions.en: In this episode, we head out in search of the roots of Kamagami. A mask hung on the walls of many homes in the north of Miyagi Prefecture and the south of Iwate Prefecture, Kamagami is believed to be a god that protects the home. Some believe that origins of this practice can be traced back to tatara iron making, which esteems the fire deity greatly. Why, then, has this practice only remained in Miyagi and Iwate? Much of this can be attributed to the craftsmen groups and Kezen carpenters who originated from Rikuzentakata City.
descriptions.ja: 今回は宮城県の北部と岩手県の南部の民家に見られる魔よけの面、カマ神のルーツを探ります。カマ神は「かまど」、つまり家を守る神として家の壁に掛けられてきました。面を掛ける風習は火の神に守られて行った「たたら製鉄」が元になったという説もあります。では何故、宮城と岩手にだけこの風習が残っているのか、そこには陸前高田が発祥の地とされている技能集団、気仙大工たちが大きく関わっていました。

titles.en: Visiting Sacred Places of the Tohoku Region
titles.fr: Les anciens lieux saints de la région de Tohoku
titles.es: Visitando Lugares Sagrados en la Región Tohoku
titles.it: Visita ai luoghi sacri nella regione Tohoku.

titles.ja: 秋田県 大湯環状列石
titles.en: The Oyu Stone Circles of Akita Prefecture
titles.it: I cerchi di pietre a Oyu nella prefettura di Akita

en: -　The culture of the Jomon people –
ja: ～東北で暮らした縄文人の文化～

descriptions.en: In this episode, we visit the Oyu Stone Circle, a historic ruin of Jomon era located in Kazuno City, Akita Prefecture. Approximately 4000 years ago, Jomon people who inhabited this land brought and embedded stones into the ground in the formation of a circle, creating the Oyu Stone Circle we see today. It is believed to have been made as a grave site at that time. Earthen figures found through excavating the surrounding land has led to speculation that festivals also took place in this area, making the Stone Circle a fragment of the life and culture of Jomon.
descriptions.ja: 今回は秋田県鹿角市にある縄文時代の遺跡、大湯環状列石を訪ねます。今からおよそ4000年前、この地で暮らした縄文人はここに石を運んで円形に組み敷きました。これが環状列石です。当時のお墓の役目を果たしたと考えられています。その周りから出土した土偶から推測すると、人々はこの周りで祭りを行なうなど、縄文の暮らしと文化の一端が見えてきます。

titles.ja: 下北半島の奇習　おこもり ～幸福の願いを込めた伝統行事～
titles.en: Okomori: The Unusual Custom of Shimokita
titles.it: Okomori: l'usanza curiosa di Shimokita

descriptions.en: In this episode, we introduce 'Okomori', a traditional ritual that has been passed down since the Edo period. We visit Sai-mura, a fishing village located on Shimokita Peninsula of Aomori Prefecture, where this unorthodox ritual takes place every December and January to pray for a big catch and good health. Villagers gather at the Ushitaki Shrine, where, at a signal, they simultaneously raise their chopsticks. While continuously shouting "meshi!" (lit. "rice!") and "shiru!" (lit. "soup!"), they proceed to enjoy their rice and soup to their stomachs' content.
descriptions.ja: 今回は青森県下北半島の漁村、佐井村を訪ね、江戸時代から続く伝統行事「おこもり」を紹介します。12月と1月に行なわれるこの変わった習慣は、大漁や無病息災を祈る行事で、願掛けの仕方が一風変わっています。会場の牛滝神明宮に詰め掛けた村人たちは合図とともに一斉に箸をあげ、「めし！」「しる！」と叫びながらご飯や汁物を満腹になるまで食べ続けるのです。
